you should note that the loop you made isnt even rigidly connected.

Whether or not it's intended, it's not logical and it's not there to keep you from building in a loop.

I can usually get around it by adding pieces, moving things around, and then deleting the extra but that doesn't always work. In your example there, you could delete the middle struts now that you have the orange tanks where you want them. Maybe. Unless KSP deletes the tank too.

Well I dunno about rigid, but she flys as-is.

But again... The snap-to, is there a way around it?

KSP builds things by linking parts in a parent-daughter relation

so one parent to one (or more) daughter

if you remove one daughter; all its descendants are removed.

--

ie. if you remove any strut which is indeed the real connecting one; you'll remove all the subsequent construction

I think what OP means, is, the tank's center is the only thing that'll snap to that strut. He can't, in example, connect the top edge of the tank to the strut.

I concur. It's a pain and it does limit design. But I have no idea how you'd intelligently fix that. Anything really complex building, and it'll never know where you meant that part to snap. There might be twelve other parts that tank overlaps and it could then snap to any one of those. So how is KSP supposed to know which parts you wanna connect?
You want to use struit connectors on the last connection so you get an even connection all around.

You want to use struit connectors on the last connection so you get an even connection all around.

He's not talking about the mother->daugher system.

He's talking about the way objects snap to the mouse.

Ignoring all of the pointless posts about structural graphs, since they're completely irrelevant to the OP's question...

The solution I use to this problem is to attach another part - in your case, the wide but short fuel tank will work - to the top and bottom of each of your orange tanks, then attach the girders to those.
